case_name: Brundaban Nayak v. Election Commission of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 50 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 50 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from order dated January 6, 1965 of Circuit Bench of Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 8-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated January 6, 1965 of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 8-D of 1965.

facts.text: Brundaban Nayak elected to Legislative Assembly of Orissa from Hinjili 23 Constituency in Ganjam district in 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Brundaban Nayak was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Orissa from the Hinjili 23 Constituency in Ganjam district in 1961,

facts.text: Brundaban Nayak appointed one of the Ministers of the Council of Ministers in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: and was appointed one of the Ministers of the Council of Ministers in the said State.

facts.text: P. Biswal applied to Governor of Orissa on August 18, 1964 alleging Brundaban Nayak incurred disqualification under Art. 191(1)(e) read with section 7 of Representation of the People Act, 1951 subsequent to election.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1964, respondent No. 2, P. Biswal, applied to the Governor of Orissa alleging that the appellant had incurred a disqualification subsequent to his election under Art. 191(1)(e) of the Constitution read with section 7 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 (No. 43 of 1951) hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Chief Secretary to Government of Orissa forwarded complaint to Election Commission on September 10, 1964 under instructions of Governor.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1964, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Orissa forwarded the ,said complaint to respondent No. 1, the Election Commission of India, under the instructions of the Governor.

facts.text: Election Commission served notice on appellant on November 17, 1964 forwarding copy of letter from respondent No. 2 dated November 4, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On November 17, 1964, respondent No. 1 served a notice on the appellant forwarding to him a copy of the letter received by it from respondent No. 2 dated the 4th November, 1964.

facts.text: Notice called for appellant's reply with affidavits by December 5, 1964 and hearing on December 8, 1964 at 10:30 A.M.

anchor.surface_text: The notice intimated to the appellant that respondent No. 1 proposed to enquire in the matter before giving its opinion on the Governors reference, and, therefore, called upon him to submit on or before the 5th December, 1964, his reply with supporting affidavits and documents, if any. The appellant was also told that the parties would be heard in person or through authorised counsel at 10-30 A.M. on the 8th December, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant sent telegram and registered letter to Election Commission on December 1, 1964 requesting adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: On December 1, 1964, the appellant sent a telegram to respondent No. 1 requesting it to adjourn the hearing of the matter. On the same day, he also addressed a registered letter to respondent No. 1 making the same request.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 objected to appellant's adjournment request.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 objected to the request made by the appellant for adjourning the hearing of the complaint.

facts.text: On December 8, 1964, Election Commission considered matter; respondent No. 2 appeared by counsel, appellant absent.

anchor.surface_text: On December 8, 1964. respondent No. 1 took up this matter for consideration. Respondent No. 2 appeared by his counsel Mr. Chatterjee, but the appellant was absent.

facts.text: Election Commission gave appellant time until January 2, 1965, 10:30 A.M. for hearing.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, respondent No. 1 gave the appellant time until the 2nd January, 1965, 10-30 A.M. when it ordered that the matter would be heard.

facts.text: On January 2, 1965, appellant appeared by counsel Mr. Patnaik, raised question of maintainability and competence.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1965, the appellant appeared by his counsel Mr. Patnaik and respondent No. 2 by his counsel Mr. Chatterjee. On this occasion, Mr. Patnaik raised the question about the maintainability of the proceedings before respondent No. 1 and its competence to hold the enquiry.

facts.text: Election Commission overruled Mr. Patnaik's contention on competence under Art. 192(2).

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 over-ruled Mr. Patnaiks contention and recorded its conclusion that it was competent to hold the enquiry under Art. 192(2).

facts.text: Appellant asked for adjournment without submitting to jurisdiction; Election Commission heard respondent No. 2's counsel and reserved orders.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Patnaik then asked for adjournment and made it clear that he was making the motion for adjournment without submitting to the jurisdiction of respondent No. 1. ... After hearing Mr. Chatterjee. respondent No. 1 reserved its orders on the enquiry

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Punjab High Court under Art. 226 to quash enquiry; summarily dismissed on January 6, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: When matters had reached this stage before respondent No. 1, the appellant moved the Punjab High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the enquiry which respondent No. 1 was holding, should be quashed on the ground that it was incompetent and without jurisdiction. This writ petition was summarily dismissed by the said High Court on January 6, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant applied for special leave on January 8, 1965; granted on January 14, 1965; stay of proceedings granted.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant applied to this Court for special leave on January 8, 1965, and special leave was granted to him on January 14, 1965. The appellant then moved this Court for stay of further proceedings before respondent No. 1, and the said prayer was granted.

facts.text: It is not disputed that complaint was made by respondent No. 2 to Governor and Governor referred to Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us, it is not disputed by the appellant that a complaint was in fact made by respondent No. 2 before the Governor of Orissa and that the Governor had then referred the matter to respondent No. 1 for its opinion.

facts.text: Notice of November 17, 1964 did not forward original complaint and Governor's reference due to oversight.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the affidavit filed by Mr. Prakash Narain. Secretary to respondent No. 1, that when notice issued by respondent No. 1 on the 17th November, 1964, was served on the appellant, through oversight the original complaint filed by respondent No. 2 before the Governor of Orissa and the reference made by the Governor to respondent No. 1 were not forwarded to the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Disqualification alleged under Art. 191(1)(e) read with s.7(d) of the Act incurred subsequent to election.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, respondent No. 2s case is that the appellant has incurred the disqualification under Art. 191(1)(e) read with s. 7(d) of the Act, and this disqualification has been incurred by him subsequent to his election.

facts.text: Chief Election Commissioner observed on May 30, 1964 on similar matter regarding Mr. Biren Mitra.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn by the learned Attorney-General to the observations made by the Chief Election Commissioner when he rendered his opinion to the Governor on May 30, 1964, on a similar question under Art. 192(2) in respect of the alleged disqualification of Mr. Biren Mitra,

When matters had reached this stage before respondent No. 1, the appellant moved the Punjab High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the enquiry which respondent No. 1 was holding, should be quashed on the ground that it was incompetent and without jurisdiction. This writ petition was summarily dismissed by the said High Court on January 6, 1965.
The principal question which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the companystruction of Article 192 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Let us then refer to Article 192 which fails to be companystrued in the present appeal. Before reading this articl, it is relevant to refer to Art. 191. Article 191(1) provides that a person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State if, to the Governor.

Before reading this articl, it is relevant to refer to Art. 191. Article 191(1) provides that a person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State if, to the Governor.

Reverting then to Art. 192, the question which we have to decide in the present appeal is whether respondent No. 1 is entitled to hold an enquiry before giving its opinion to the Governor as required by Art. 192(2). Let us read Art. 192-- If any question arises as to whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of Article 191, the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor and his decision shall be final.

As we have already indicated, respondent No. 2s case is that the appellant has incurred the disqualification under Art. 191(1)(e) read with s. 7(d) of the Act, and this disqualification has been incurred by him subsequent to his election. It is well-settled that the disqualification to which Art. 191(1) refers, must be incurred subsequent to the election of the member. This conclusion follows from the provisions of Art. 190(3)(a).

concepts.interpretation: Provides for vacation of seat if member becomes subject to disqualification in Art. 191(1).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: hold the enquiry and then forward to the Election Commission all the material companylected in such an enquiry to enable it to form its opinion and co

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad refers to the fact that Art. 192 occurs in Chapter III of Part VI which deals with the State Legislature, and he invited our attention to the fact that under Art. 199(3) which deals with a question as to whether a Bill introduced in the Legislature of a State which has a Legislative Council is a Money Bill or not, the decision of the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of such State thereon shall be final.

Similarly, all complaints in respect of disqualifications subsequently incurred by members who have been validly elected, have, in substance, to be tried by the Election Commission, though the decision in form has to be pronounced by the Governor. If this scheme of Art. 192(1) and (2) is borne in mind, there would be no difficulty in rejecting Mr. Setalvads contention that the enquiry must be held by the Governor.

concepts.interpretation: Analogous provision for Parliament; EC holds enquiry before opinion to President.

issues.text: The principal question which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the construction of Article 192 of the Constitution.

issues.text: the question which we have to decide in the present appeal is whether respondent No. 1 is entitled to hold an enquiry before giving its opinion to the Governor as required by Art. 192(2)

anchor.surface_text: Reverting then to Art. 192, the question which we have to decide in the present appeal is whether respondent No. 1 is entitled to hold an enquiry before giving its opinion to the Governor as required by Art. 192 2 . Let us read Art. 192-- If any question arises as to whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause  1  of Article 191, the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor and his decision shall be final.

issues.text: whether in the present case, no question can be said to have arisen as to whether the appellant has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of Art. 191, because such a question can be raised only on the floor of the Legislative Assembly and not by an ordinary citizen or voter in the form of a complaint to the Governor

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the appellant contends that in the present case. no question can be said to have arisen as to whether the appellant has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause  1  of Art. 191, because his case is that such a question can be raised only on the floor of the Legislative Assembly and can be raised by members of the Assembly and not by an ordinary citizen or voter in the form of a complaint to the Governor.

issues.text: whether even if a question is held to have arisen under Art. 192(1), it is for the Governor to hold the enquiry and not for the Election Commission

anchor.surface_text: The next point which Mr. Setalvad has raised is that even if a question is held to have arisen under Art. 192 1 , it is for the Governor to hold the enquiry and not for the Election Commission. He contends that Art. 192 1  requires the question to be referred to the Governor for his decision and provides that his decision shall be final.

issues.text: whether the failure of respondent No. 1 to furnish the appellant with a copy of the complaint made by respondent No. 2 before the Governor and of the order of reference passed by the Governor rendered the proceedings before respondent No. 1 illegal

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad faintly attempted to argue that the failure of respondent No. 1 to furnish the appellant with a copy of the complaint made by respondent No. 2 before the Governor and of the order of reference passed by the Governor ,forwarding the said complaint to respondent No. 1, rendered the proceedings before respondent No. 1 illegal.

arguments.claim: No question has arisen under Art. 192(1) because such a question can only be raised on the floor of the Legislative Assembly by members, not by an ordinary citizen or voter via complaint to Governor

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the appellant contends that in the present case. no question can be said to have arisen as to whether the appellant has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of Art. 191, because his case is that such a question can be raised only on the floor of the Legislative Assembly and can be raised by members of the Assembly and not by an ordinary citizen or voter in the form of a complaint to the Governor.

arguments.court_reasoning: No such limitation in words of Art. 192(1)

arguments.claim: Art. 192(2) should not require Governor to refer every frivolous complaint to EC

anchor.surface_text: There is another argument which he has advanced before us in support of this construction. Article 192(2) requires that whenever a question is referred to the Governor, he shall obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and Mr. Setalvad suggests that it could not have been the intention of the Constitution to require the Governor to refer to the Election Commission every question which is raised about an alleged disqualification of a member of a Legislative Assembly even though such a question may be patently frivolous or unsustainable.

arguments.claim: Any question under Art. 192(1) arises regardless of how, by whom, or circumstances; citizen can complain

anchor.surface_text: What the said clause requires is that a question should arise how it arises, by whom it is raised, in what circumstances it is raised, are not relevant for the purpose of the application of this clause.

arguments.claim: Words 'shall be referred for decision of Governor' mean Governor alone decides, no prior referring authority needed

anchor.surface_text: Then as to the argument based on the words the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor, these words do not import the assumption that any other authority has to receive the complaint and after a prima facie and initial investigation about the complaint, send it on or refer it to the Governor for his decision.

arguments.claim: EC can reject frivolous complaints; object of Art. 192 and 190(3)(a) allows any citizen complaint for legislative purity

anchor.surface_text: It is conceivable that in some cases, complaints made to the Governor may be frivolous or fantastic but if they are of such a character, the Election Commission will find no difficulty in expressing its opinion that they should be rejected straightaway. The object of Art. 192 is plain.

arguments.claim: Under Art. 192 scheme, EC opinion decisive; Governor bound, does not consult ministers or decide himself; EC holds enquiry

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of Article 192(1) and (2) is absolutely clear. The decision on the question raised under Art. 192(1) has no doubt to be pronounced by the Governor, but that decision has to be in accordance with the opinion of the Election Commission.

arguments.claim: Analogous to election petitions tried by EC tribunals and Art. 103(2) where EC enquires before opinion to President

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, all complaints in respect of disqualifications subsequently incurred by members who have been validly elected, have, in substance, to be tried by the Election Commission, though the decision in form has to be pronounced by the Governor. If this scheme of Art. 192(1) and (2) is borne in mind, there would be no difficulty in rejecting Mr. Setalvads contention that the enquiry must be held by the Governor.

arguments.claim: Consistent practice: EC holds enquiries under Art. 192(2) and 103(2) without challenge

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we ought to point out that so far the practice followed in respect of such complaints has consistently recognised that the enquiry is to be held by the Election Commission both under Art. 192(2) and Art. 103(2).

arguments.claim: Oversight in not forwarding original documents does not affect EC jurisdiction; appellant aware

anchor.surface_text: This contention is plainly misconceived. As soon as respondent No. 1 received the complaint and the order of reference which was communicated to it by the Chief Secretary to the Government of Orissa, it was seized of the matter and it was plainly acting within its jurisdiction under Art. 192(2) when it served the notice on the appellant.

holdings.text: A question under Article 192(1) arises if any question as to whether a member has become subject to disqualification under Article 191(1), regardless of how, by whom, or in what circumstances it arises; any citizen may complain to the Governor.

anchor.surface_text: What the said clause requires is that a question should arise how it arises, by whom it is raised, in what circumstances it is raised, are not relevant for the purpose of the application of this clause. All that is relevant is that a question of the type mentioned by the clause should arise and so, the limitation which Mr. Setalvad seeks to introduce in the construction of the first part of Art. 192(1) is plainly inconsistent with the words used in the said clause. Then as to the argument based on the words the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor, these words do not import the assumption that any other authority has to receive the complaint and after a prima facie and initial investigation about the complaint, send it on or refer it to the Governor for his decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of Art. 192(1) imposes no limits on mode of arising; purposive to ensure no disqualified member continues; rejects floor-of-House or Speaker referral requirements.

holdings.text: Under Article 192(2), the Election Commission is entitled to and competent to hold an enquiry before giving its opinion on the Governor's reference.

anchor.surface_text: Reverting then to Art. 192, the question which we have to decide in the present appeal is whether respondent No. 1 is entitled to hold an enquiry before giving its opinion to the Governor as required by Art. 192(2). Let us read Art. 192-- If any question arises as to whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of Article 191, the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor and his decision shall be final.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 192(2) requires Governor to obtain EC opinion and act according to it; EC effectively decides.

holdings.text: The enquiry under Article 192 is to be held by the Election Commission, not the Governor; Governor is bound by EC opinion and merely pronounces it.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of Article 192(1) and (2) is absolutely clear. The decision on the question raised under Art. 192(1) has no doubt to be pronounced by the Governor, but that decision has to be in accordance with the opinion of the Election Commission. The object of this provision clearly is to leave it to the Election Commission to decide the matter, though the decision as such would formally be pronounced in the name of the Governor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional scheme makes EC opinion decisive; Governor has no independent decision-making role; analogous to election petitions and Art. 103.

holdings.text: Failure to furnish copies of original complaint and Governor's reference due to oversight does not render EC proceedings illegal or affect jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad faintly attempted to argue that the failure of respondent No. 1 to furnish the appellant with a copy of the complaint made by respondent No. 2 before the Governor and of the order of reference passed by the Governor, forwarding the said complaint to respondent No. 1, rendered the proceedings before respondent No. 1 illegal. This contention is plainly misconceived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: EC seized of jurisdiction upon receipt from Governor; appellant aware of proceedings; mere oversight non-fatal.

holdings.text: Consistent practice recognizes that enquiries under Art. 192(2) and Art. 103(2) are held by the Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we ought to point out that so far the practice followed in respect of such complaints has consistently recognised that the enquiry is to be held by the Election Commission both under Art. 192(2) and Art. 103(2). In fact, the learned Attorney General for respondent No. 1 stated before us that though on several occasions, the Election Commission has held enquiries before communicating its opinion either to the President under Art. 103(2) or to the Governor under Art. 192(2), no one ever thought of raising the contention that the enquiry must be held by the President or the Governor respectively under Art. 103(1) and Art. 192(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long-standing unchallenged practice confirms EC's role in holding enquiries.

holdings.text: It is desirable that Parliament vest the Election Commission with powers of a commission under the Commissions of Enquiry Act, 1952 for enquiries under Art. 192(2).

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn by the learned Attorney-General to the observations made by the Chief Election Commissioner when he rendered his opinion to the Governor on May 30, 1964, on a similar question under Art. 192(2) in respect of the alleged disqualification of Mr. Biren Mitra,... It is desirable that the Election Commission should be vested with the powers of a commission under the Commissions of Enquiry Act, 1952, such as the power to summon witnesses and examine them on oath, the power to compel the production of documents, and the power to issue commissions for the examination of witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: EC faces difficulties without powers to summon/ examine witnesses; invites legislative action.

precedents.citation: Election Commission, India Saka Venkata Subba Rao and Union of lndia--Intervener

anchor.surface_text: Election Commission, India Saka Venkata Subba Rao and Union of lndia--Intervener that Articles 190 3  and 192 1  are applicable only to disqualifications to which a member becomes subject after being elected as such. There is nodoubt

precedents.case_name: Election Commission of India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: Articles 190(3) and 192(1) are applicable only to disqualifications to which a member becomes subject after being elected as such.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. In view of the fact that the present proceedings have unnecessarily protracted the enquiry before respondent No. 1, we suggest that respondent No. 1 should proceed to consider the matter and forward its opinion to the Governor as early as possible. It is hardly necessary to point out that in case the allegations made against the appellant are found to be valid, and the opinion of respondent No.1 is in favour of the case set out by respondent No. 2, complications may arise by reason of the Constitutional provision prescribed by Art. 190 3 . In view of the said provision, it is of utmost importance that companyplaints made under Art.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against the Election Commission's competence to hold inquiry under Article 192 dismissed; proceedings before Election Commission upheld
directions: respondent No. 1 should proceed to consider the matter and forward its opinion to the Governor as early as possible

anchor.surface_text: ed by the Election Commission in rendering its opinion under Art. 103 2  or Art. 192 2  appears to be genuine, and so Parliament may well companysider

edges.explanation: Argument on consistent practice of EC holding enquiries under Art. 192(2) and 103(2) without challenge directly supports the holding recognizing that consistent practice.
General consistent practice claim in a7 is elaborated and supported by specific unchallenged practice examples under Art. 192(2) and 103(2) in a16.
Argument noting consistent practice where EC holds enquiry before opinion supports the holding on consistent practice of EC holding such enquiries.
The holding on the non-impact of failure to furnish copies is made within the exercise of powers under Article 226.
Article 226 of the Constitution provides the writ jurisdiction under which the issue concerning the validity of EC proceedings is addressed.

anchor.surface_text: What the said clause requires is that a question should arise how it arises, by whom it is raised, in what circumstances it is raised, are not relevant for the purpose of the application of this clause. All that is relevant is that a question of the type mentioned by the clause should arise and so, the limitation which Mr. Setalvad seeks to introduce in the construction of the first part of Art. 192(1) is plainly inconsistent with the words used in the said clause. Then as to the argument based on the words the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor, these words do not import the assumption that any other authority has to receive the complaint and after a prima facie and initial investigation about the complaint, send it on or refer it to the Governor for his decision.

The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. In view of the fact that the present proceedings have unnecessarily protracted the enquiry before respondent No. 1, we suggest that respondent No. 1 should proceed to consider the matter and forward its opinion to the Governor as early as possible. It is hardly necessary to point out that in case the allegations made against the appellant are found to be valid, and the opinion of respondent No.1 is in favour of the case set out by respondent No. 2, complications may arise by reason of the Constitutional provision prescribed by Art. 190 3 . In view of the said provision, it is of utmost importance that companyplaints made under Art.

Reverting then to Art. 192, the question which we have to decide in the present appeal is whether respondent No. 1 is entitled to hold an enquiry before giving its opinion to the Governor as required by Art. 192(2). Let us read Art. 192-- If any question arises as to whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of Article 191, the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor and his decision shall be final.

The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. In view of the fact that the present proceedings have unnecessarily protracted the enquiry before respondent No. 1, we suggest that respondent No. 1 should proceed to consider the matter and forward its opinion to the Governor as early as possible. It is hardly necessary to point out that in case the allegations made against the appellant are found to be valid, and the opinion of respondent No.1 is in favour of the case set out by respondent No. 2, complications may arise by reason of the Constitutional provision prescribed by Art. 190 3 . In view of the said provision, it is of utmost importance that companyplaints made under Art.

The scheme of Article 192(1) and (2) is absolutely clear. The decision on the question raised under Art. 192(1) has no doubt to be pronounced by the Governor, but that decision has to be in accordance with the opinion of the Election Commission. The object of this provision clearly is to leave it to the Election Commission to decide the matter, though the decision as such would formally be pronounced in the name of the Governor.

The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. In view of the fact that the present proceedings have unnecessarily protracted the enquiry before respondent No. 1, we suggest that respondent No. 1 should proceed to consider the matter and forward its opinion to the Governor as early as possible. It is hardly necessary to point out that in case the allegations made against the appellant are found to be valid, and the opinion of respondent No.1 is in favour of the case set out by respondent No. 2, complications may arise by reason of the Constitutional provision prescribed by Art. 190 3 . In view of the said provision, it is of utmost importance that companyplaints made under Art.

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly resolves the issue by stating that the failure due to oversight does not render proceedings illegal or affect jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad faintly attempted to argue that the failure of respondent No. 1 to furnish the appellant with a copy of the complaint made by respondent No. 2 before the Governor and of the order of reference passed by the Governor, forwarding the said complaint to respondent No. 1, rendered the proceedings before respondent No. 1 illegal. This contention is plainly misconceived.

The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. In view of the fact that the present proceedings have unnecessarily protracted the enquiry before respondent No. 1, we suggest that respondent No. 1 should proceed to consider the matter and forward its opinion to the Governor as early as possible.
